lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: Spotted, detested, and abominable.
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: Why are you sequester'd from all your train,
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: Dismounted from your snow-white goodly steed.
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: And wander'd hither to an obscure plot,
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: Accompanied but with a barbarous Moor,
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: If foul desire had not conducted you?
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: And, being intercepted in your sport,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Great reason that my noble lord be rated
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: For sauciness. I pray you, let us hence,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: And let her joy her raven-colour'd love;
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: This valley fits the purpose passing well.
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: BASSIANUS
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: The king my brother shall have note of this.
lines.speaker: BASSIANUS

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Ay, for these slips have made him noted long:
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Good king, to be so mightily abused!
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Why have I patience to endure all this?
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: How now, dear sovereign, and our gracious mother!
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Why doth your highness look so pale and wan?
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Have I not reason, think you, to look pale?
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: These two have 'ticed me hither to this place:
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: A barren detested vale, you see it is;
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: The trees, though summer, yet forlorn and lean,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: O'ercome with moss and baleful mistletoe:
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Here never shines the sun; here nothing breeds,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Unless the nightly owl or fatal raven:
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: And when they show'd me this abhorred pit,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: They told me, here, at dead time of the night,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: A thousand fiends, a thousand hissing snakes,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Ten thousand swelling toads, as many urchins,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Would make such fearful and confused cries
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: As any mortal body hearing it
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Should straight fall mad, or else die suddenly.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: No sooner had they told this hellish tale,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: But straight they told me they would bind me here
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Unto the body of a dismal yew,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: And leave me to this miserable death:
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: And then they call'd me foul adulteress,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: That ever ear did hear to such effect:
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: And, had you not by wondrous fortune come,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: This vengeance on me had they executed.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Revenge it, as you love your mother's life,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Or be ye not henceforth call'd my children.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: This is a witness that I am thy son.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: And this for me, struck home to show my strength.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Ay, come, Semiramis, nay, barbarous Tamora,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: For no name fits thy nature but thy own!
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Give me thy poniard; you shall know, my boys
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Stay, madam; here is more belongs to her;
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: First thrash the corn, then after burn the straw:
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: This minion stood upon her chastity,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Upon her nuptial vow, her loyalty,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: And with that painted hope braves your mightiness:
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: And shall she carry this unto her grave?
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: An if she do, I would I were an eunuch.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: Drag hence her husband to some secret hole,
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: And make his dead trunk pillow to our lust.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: But when ye have the honey ye desire,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Let not this wasp outlive, us both to sting.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: I warrant you, madam, we wil l make that sure.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: Come, mistress, now perforce we will enjoy
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: That nice-preserved honesty of yours.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: O Tamora! thou bear'st a woman's face,--
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: I will not hear her speak; away with her!
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Sweet lords, entreat her hear me but a word.
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Listen, fair madam: let it be your glory
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: To see her tears; but be your heart to them
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: When did the tiger's young ones teach the dam?
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: O, do not learn her wrath; she taught it thee;
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: The milk thou suck'dst from her did turn to marble;
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Even at thy teat thou hadst thy tyranny.
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Yet every mother breeds not sons alike:
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Do thou entreat her show a woman pity.
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: What, wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: 'Tis true; the raven doth not hatch a lark:
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Yet have I heard,--O, could I find it now!--
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: The lion moved with pity did endure
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: To have his princely paws pared all away:
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Some say that ravens foster forlorn children,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: The whilst their own birds famish in their nests:
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: O, be to me, though thy hard heart say no,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Nothing so kind, but something pitiful!
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: I know not what it means; away with her!
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: O, let me teach thee! for my father's sake,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: That gave thee life, when well he might have
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: slain thee,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Be not obdurate, open thy deaf ears.
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Even for his sake am I pitiless.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Remember, boys, I pour'd forth tears in vain,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: To save your brother from the sacrifice;
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: But fierce Andronicus would not relent;
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Therefore, away with her, and use her as you will,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: The worse to her, the better loved of me.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: O Tamora, be call'd a gentle queen,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: And with thine own hands kill me in this place!
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: For 'tis not life that I have begg'd so long;
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Poor I was slain when Bassianus died.
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: What begg'st thou, then? fond woman, let me go.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: 'Tis present death I beg; and one thing more
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: O, keep me from their worse than killing lust,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: And tumble me into some loathsome pit,
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Where never man's eye may behold my body:
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Do this, and be a charitable murderer.
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: So should I rob my sweet sons of their fee:
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Away! for thou hast stay'd us here too long.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: LAVINIA
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: No grace? no womanhood? Ah, beastly creature!
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: The blot and enemy to our general name!
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: Confusion fall--
lines.speaker: LAVINIA

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: Nay, then I'll stop your mouth. Bring thou her husband:
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Farewell, my sons: see that you make her sure.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Ne'er let my heart know merry cheer indeed,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Till all the Andronici be made away.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moor,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: And let my spleenful sons this trull deflow'r.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Come on, my lords, the better foot before:
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Straight will I bring you to the loathsome pit
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Where I espied the panther fast asleep.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: QUINTUS
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: My sight is very dull, whate'er it bodes.
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: And mine, I promise you; were't not for shame,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Well could I leave our sport to sleep awhile.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: QUINTUS
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: What art thou fall'n? What subtle hole is this,
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Whose mouth is cover'd with rude-growing briers,
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Upon whose leaves are drops of new-shed blood
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: As fresh as morning dew distill'd on flowers?
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: A very fatal place it seems to me.
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Speak, brother, hast thou hurt thee with the fall?
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: O brother, with the dismall'st object hurt
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: That ever eye with sight made heart lament!
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: [Aside]  Now will I fetch the king to find them here,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: That he thereby may give a likely guess
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: How these were they that made away his brother.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Why dost not comfort me, and help me out
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: From this unhallowed and blood-stained hole?
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: QUINTUS
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: I am surprised with an uncouth fear;
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: A chilling sweat o'er-runs my trembling joints:
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: To prove thou hast a true-divining heart,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Aaron and thou look down into this den,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: And see a fearful sight of blood and death.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: QUINTUS
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Aaron is gone; and my compassionate heart
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Will not permit mine eyes once to behold
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: The thing whereat it trembles by surmise;
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: O, tell me how it is; for ne'er till now
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Was I a child to fear I know not what.
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Lord Bassianus lies embrewed here,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: All on a heap, like to a slaughter'd lamb,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: QUINTUS
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: If it be dark, how dost thou know 'tis he?
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Upon his bloody finger he doth wear
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: A precious ring, that lightens all the hole,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Which, like a taper in some monument,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Doth shine upon the dead man's earthy cheeks,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: And shows the ragged entrails of the pit:
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: So pale did shine the moon on Pyramus
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: When he by night lay bathed in maiden blood.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: O brother, help me with thy fainting hand--
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: If fear hath made thee faint, as me it hath--
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Out of this fell devouring receptacle,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: As hateful as Cocytus' misty mouth.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: QUINTUS
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Reach me thy hand, that I may help thee out;
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Or, wanting strength to do thee so much good,
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: I may be pluck'd into the swallowing womb
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Of this deep pit, poor Bassianus' grave.
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: I have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Nor I no strength to climb without thy help.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: QUINTUS
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Thy hand once more; I will not loose again,
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Till thou art here aloft, or I below:
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: Thou canst not come to me: I come to thee.
lines.speaker: QUINTUS

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Along with me: I'll see what hole is here,
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: And what he is that now is leap'd into it.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Say who art thou that lately didst descend
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Into this gaping hollow of the earth?
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: The unhappy son of old Andronicus:
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: Brought hither in a most unlucky hour,
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: To find thy brother Bassianus dead.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: My brother dead! I know thou dost but jest:
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: He and his lady both are at the lodge
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Upon the north side of this pleasant chase;
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: 'Tis not an hour since I left him there.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: MARTIUS
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: We know not where you left him all alive;
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: But, out, alas! here have we found him dead.
lines.speaker: MARTIUS

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Where is my lord the king?
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Here, Tamora, though grieved with killing grief.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Where is thy brother Bassianus?
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound:
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Then all too late I bring this fatal writ,
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: The complot of this timeless tragedy;
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: And wonder greatly that man's face can fold
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: [Reads]  'An if we miss to meet him handsomely--
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Sweet huntsman, Bassianus 'tis we mean--
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Do thou so much as dig the grave for him:
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Thou know'st our meaning. Look for thy reward
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Among the nettles at the elder-tree
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Which overshades the mouth of that same pit
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Where we decreed to bury Bassianus.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Do this, and purchase us thy lasting friends.'
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: O Tamora! was ever heard the like?
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: This is the pit, and this the elder-tree.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Look, sirs, if you can find the huntsman out
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: That should have murdered Bassianus here.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: My gracious lord, here is the bag of gold.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: [To TITUS]  Two of thy whelps, fell curs of
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: bloody kind,
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Have here bereft my brother of his life.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Sirs, drag them from the pit unto the prison:
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: There let them bide until we have devised
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: What, are they in this pit? O wondrous thing!
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: How easily murder is discovered!
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: High emperor, upon my feeble knee
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: I beg this boon, with tears not lightly shed,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That this fell fault of my accursed sons,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Accursed if the fault be proved in them,--
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: If it be proved! you see it is apparent.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Who found this letter? Tamora, was it you?
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Andronicus himself did take it up.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: I did, my lord: yet let me be their bail;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For, by my father's reverend tomb, I vow
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: They shall be ready at your highness' will
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: To answer their suspicion with their lives.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: SATURNINUS
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Thou shalt not bail them: see thou follow me.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Some bring the murder'd body, some the murderers:
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: Let them not speak a word; the guilt is plain;
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: For, by my soul, were there worse end than death,
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: That end upon them should be executed.
lines.speaker: SATURNINUS

lines.value: TAMORA
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Andronicus, I will entreat the king;
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: Fear not thy sons; they shall do well enough.
lines.speaker: TAMORA

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come, Lucius, come; stay not to talk with them.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: So, now go tell, an if thy tongue can speak,
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: Who 'twas that cut thy tongue and ravish'd thee.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: Write down thy mind, bewray thy meaning so,
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: An if thy stumps will let thee play the scribe.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: See, how with signs and tokens she can scrowl.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: Go home, call for sweet water, wash thy hands.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to wash;
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: And so let's leave her to her silent walks.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: CHIRON
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: An 'twere my case, I should go hang myself.
lines.speaker: CHIRON

lines.value: DEMETRIUS
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.
lines.speaker: DEMETRIUS

lines.value: MARCUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Who is this? my niece, that flies away so fast!
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Cousin, a word; where is your husband?
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: If I do dream, would all my wealth would wake me!
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: If I do wake, some planet strike me down,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: That I may slumber in eternal sleep!
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Speak, gentle niece, what stern ungentle hands
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Have lopp'd and hew'd and made thy body bare
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Of her two branches, those sweet ornaments,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Whose circling shadows kings have sought to sleep in,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: And might not gain so great a happiness
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: As have thy love? Why dost not speak to me?
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Alas, a crimson river of warm blood,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Like to a bubbling fountain stirr'd with wind,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Doth rise and fall between thy rosed lips,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Coming and going with thy honey breath.
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: But, sure, some Tereus hath deflowered thee,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: And, lest thou shouldst detect him, cut thy tongue.
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Ah, now thou turn'st away thy face for shame!
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: And, notwithstanding all this loss of blood,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: As from a conduit with three issuing spouts,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Yet do thy cheeks look red as Titan's face
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Blushing to be encountered with a cloud.
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Shall I speak for thee? shall I say 'tis so?
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: O, that I knew thy heart; and knew the beast,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: That I might rail at him, to ease my mind!
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Sorrow concealed, like an oven stopp'd,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Doth burn the heart to cinders where it is.
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Fair Philomela, she but lost her tongue,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: And in a tedious sampler sew'd her mind:
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: But, lovely niece, that mean is cut from thee;
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: A craftier Tereus, cousin, hast thou met,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: And he hath cut those pretty fingers off,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: That could have better sew'd than Philomel.
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: O, had the monster seen those lily hands
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Tremble, like aspen-leaves, upon a lute,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: And make the silken strings delight to kiss them,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: He would not then have touch'd them for his life!
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Or, had he heard the heavenly harmony
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Which that sweet tongue hath made,
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: He would have dropp'd his knife, and fell asleep
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: As Cerberus at the Thracian poet's feet.
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Come, let us go, and make thy father blind;
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: For such a sight will blind a father's eye:
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: One hour's storm will drown the fragrant meads;
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: What will whole months of tears thy father's eyes?
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: Do not draw back, for we will mourn with thee
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: O, could our mourning ease thy misery!
lines.speaker: MARCUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Hear me, grave fathers! noble tribunes, stay!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For pity of mine age, whose youth was spent
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: In dangerous wars, whilst you securely slept;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For all my blood in Rome's great quarrel shed;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For all the frosty nights that I have watch'd;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And for these bitter tears, which now you see
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheeks;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Be pitiful to my condemned sons,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Whose souls are not corrupted as 'tis thought.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For two and twenty sons I never wept,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Because they died in honour's lofty bed.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For these, these, tribunes, in the dust I write
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: My heart's deep languor and my soul's sad tears:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Let my tears stanch the earth's dry appetite;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: My sons' sweet blood will make it shame and blush.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O earth, I will befriend thee more with rain,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That shall distil from these two ancient urns,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Than youthful April shall with all his showers:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: In summer's drought I'll drop upon thee still;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: In winter with warm tears I'll melt the snow
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And keep eternal spring-time on thy face,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: So thou refuse to drink my dear sons' blood.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O reverend tribunes! O gentle, aged men!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Unbind my sons, reverse the doom of death;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And let me say, that never wept before,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: My tears are now prevailing orators.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: O noble father, you lament in vain:
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: The tribunes hear you not; no man is by;
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: And you recount your sorrows to a stone.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Ah, Lucius, for thy brothers let me plead.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Grave tribunes, once more I entreat of you,--
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: My gracious lord, no tribune hears you speak.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Why, tis no matter, man; if they did hear,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: They would not mark me, or if they did mark,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: They would not pity me, yet plead I must;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Therefore I tell my sorrows to the stones;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Who, though they cannot answer my distress,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Yet in some sort they are better than the tribunes,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For that they will not intercept my tale:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: When I do weep, they humbly at my feet
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Receive my tears and seem to weep with me;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And, were they but attired in grave weeds,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Rome could afford no tribune like to these.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: A stone is soft as wax,--tribunes more hard than stones;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: A stone is silent, and offendeth not,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And tribunes with their tongues doom men to death.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawn?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: To rescue my two brothers from their death:
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: For which attempt the judges have pronounced
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: My everlasting doom of banishment.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O happy man! they have befriended thee.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Why, foolish Lucius, dost thou not perceive
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That Rome is but a wilderness of tigers?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Tigers must prey, and Rome affords no prey
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But me and mine: how happy art thou, then,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: From these devourers to be banished!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But who comes with our brother Marcus here?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Titus, prepare thy aged eyes to weep;
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Or, if not so, thy noble heart to break:
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: I bring consuming sorrow to thine age.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Will it consume me? let me see it, then.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: This was thy daughter.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Why, Marcus, so she is.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Ay me, this object kills me!
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Faint-hearted boy, arise, and look upon her.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Speak, Lavinia, what accursed hand
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Hath made thee handless in thy father's sight?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: What fool hath added water to the sea,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Or brought a faggot to bright-burning Troy?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: My grief was at the height before thou camest,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And now like Nilus, it disdaineth bounds.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Give me a sword, I'll chop off my hands too;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For they have fought for Rome, and all in vain;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And they have nursed this woe, in feeding life;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: In bootless prayer have they been held up,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And they have served me to effectless use:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Now all the service I require of them
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Is that the one will help to cut the other.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: 'Tis well, Lavinia, that thou hast no hands;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For hands, to do Rome service, are but vain.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Speak, gentle sister, who hath martyr'd thee?
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O, that delightful engine of her thoughts
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That blabb'd them with such pleasing eloquence,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Is torn from forth that pretty hollow cage,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Where, like a sweet melodious bird, it sung
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Sweet varied notes, enchanting every ear!
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: O, say thou for her, who hath done this deed?
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O, thus I found her, straying in the park,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Seeking to hide herself, as doth the deer
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That hath received some unrecuring wound.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: It was my deer; and he that wounded her
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Hath hurt me more than had he killed me dead:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For now I stand as one upon a rock
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Environed with a wilderness of sea,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Who marks the waxing tide grow wave by wave,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Expecting ever when some envious surge
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: This way to death my wretched sons are gone;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Here stands my other son, a banished man,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And here my brother, weeping at my woes.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Is dear Lavinia, dearer than my soul.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Had I but seen thy picture in this plight,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: It would have madded me: what shall I do
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Now I behold thy lively body so?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thou hast no hands, to wipe away thy tears:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Nor tongue, to tell me who hath martyr'd thee:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thy husband he is dead: and for his death
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thy brothers are condemn'd, and dead by this.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Look, Marcus! ah, son Lucius, look on her!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: When I did name her brothers, then fresh tears
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Stood on her cheeks, as doth the honey-dew
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Upon a gather'd lily almost wither'd.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Perchance she weeps because they kill'd her husband;
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Perchance because she knows them innocent.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: If they did kill thy husband, then be joyful
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Because the law hath ta'en revenge on them.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: No, no, they would not do so foul a deed;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Witness the sorrow that their sister makes.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Gentle Lavinia, let me kiss thy lips.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Or make some sign how I may do thee ease:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Shall thy good uncle, and thy brother Lucius,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And thou, and I, sit round about some fountain,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Looking all downwards to behold our cheeks
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: How they are stain'd, as meadows, yet not dry,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: With miry slime left on them by a flood?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And in the fountain shall we gaze so long
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Till the fresh taste be taken from that clearness,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And made a brine-pit with our bitter tears?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Or shall we cut away our hands, like thine?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Or shall we bite our tongues, and in dumb shows
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Pass the remainder of our hateful days?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: What shall we do? let us, that have our tongues,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Plot some deuce of further misery,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: To make us wonder'd at in time to come.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Sweet father, cease your tears; for, at your grief,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: See how my wretched sister sobs and weeps.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Patience, dear niece. Good Titus, dry thine eyes.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Ah, Marcus, Marcus! brother, well I wot
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For thou, poor man, hast drown'd it with thine own.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Ah, my Lavinia, I will wipe thy cheeks.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Mark, Marcus, mark! I understand her signs:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Had she a tongue to speak, now would she say
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That to her brother which I said to thee:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: His napkin, with his true tears all bewet,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Can do no service on her sorrowful cheeks.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O, what a sympathy of woe is this,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As far from help as Limbo is from bliss!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Titus Andronicus, my lord the emperor
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Sends thee this word,--that, if thou love thy sons,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself, old Titus,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Or any one of you, chop off your hand,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And send it to the king: he for the same
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Will send thee hither both thy sons alive;
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And that shall be the ransom for their fault.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O gracious emperor! O gentle Aaron!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Did ever raven sing so like a lark,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That gives sweet tidings of the sun's uprise?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: With all my heart, I'll send the emperor My hand:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Good Aaron, wilt thou help to chop it off?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Stay, father! for that noble hand of thine,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: That hath thrown down so many enemies,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Shall not be sent: my hand will serve the turn:
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: My youth can better spare my blood than you;
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: And therefore mine shall save my brothers' lives.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Which of your hands hath not defended Rome,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And rear'd aloft the bloody battle-axe,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Writing destruction on the enemy's castle?
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O, none of both but are of high desert:
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: My hand hath been but idle; let it serve
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: To ransom my two nephews from their death;
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then have I kept it to a worthy end.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Nay, come, agree whose hand shall go along,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: For fear they die before their pardon come.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: My hand shall go.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: By heaven, it shall not go!
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Sirs, strive no more: such wither'd herbs as these
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Are meet for plucking up, and therefore mine.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Sweet father, if I shall be thought thy son,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Let me redeem my brothers both from death.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And, for our father's sake and mother's care,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Now let me show a brother's love to thee.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Agree between you; I will spare my hand.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Then I'll go fetch an axe.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But I will use the axe.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come hither, Aaron; I'll deceive them both:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Lend me thy hand, and I will give thee mine.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: [Aside]  If that be call'd deceit, I will be honest,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And never, whilst I live, deceive men so:
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: But I'll deceive you in another sort,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And that you'll say, ere half an hour pass.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Now stay your strife: what shall be is dispatch'd.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Good Aaron, give his majesty my hand:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Tell him it was a hand that warded him
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: From thousand dangers; bid him bury it
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: More hath it merited; that let it have.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As for my sons, say I account of them
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As jewels purchased at an easy price;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And yet dear too, because I bought mine own.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: I go, Andronicus: and for thy hand
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Look by and by to have thy sons with thee.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Their heads, I mean. O, how this villany
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it!
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Let fools do good, and fair men call for grace.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Aaron will have his soul black like his face.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O, here I lift this one hand up to heaven,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And bow this feeble ruin to the earth:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: If any power pities wretched tears,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: To that I call!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: What, wilt thou kneel with me?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Do, then, dear heart; for heaven shall hear our prayers;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Or with our sighs we'll breathe the welkin dim,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And stain the sun with fog, as sometime clouds
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: When they do hug him in their melting bosoms.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O brother, speak with possibilities,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And do not break into these deep extremes.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Is not my sorrow deep, having no bottom?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then be my passions bottomless with them.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But yet let reason govern thy lament.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: If there were reason for these miseries,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then into limits could I bind my woes:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: When heaven doth weep, doth not the earth o'erflow?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: If the winds rage, doth not the sea wax mad,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Threatening the welkin with his big-swoln face?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And wilt thou have a reason for this coil?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: I am the sea; hark, how her sighs do blow!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: She is the weeping welkin, I the earth:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then must my sea be moved with her sighs;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then must my earth with her continual tears
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Become a deluge, overflow'd and drown'd;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For why my bowels cannot hide her woes,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But like a drunkard must I vomit them.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then give me leave, for losers will have leave
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: To ease their stomachs with their bitter tongues.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Messenger
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: Worthy Andronicus, ill art thou repaid
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: For that good hand thou sent'st the emperor.
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: Here are the heads of thy two noble sons;
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: And here's thy hand, in scorn to thee sent back;
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: Thy griefs their sports, thy resolution mock'd;
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: That woe is me to think upon thy woes
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: More than remembrance of my father's death.
lines.speaker: Messenger

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Now let hot AEtna cool in Sicily,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And be my heart an ever-burning hell!
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: These miseries are more than may be borne.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: To weep with them that weep doth ease some deal;
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But sorrow flouted at is double death.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Ah, that this sight should make so deep a wound,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: And yet detested life not shrink thereat!
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: That ever death should let life bear his name,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Where life hath no more interest but to breathe!
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Alas, poor heart, that kiss is comfortless
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As frozen water to a starved snake.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: When will this fearful slumber have an end?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Now, farewell, flattery: die, Andronicus;
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thou dost not slumber: see, thy two sons' heads,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thy warlike hand, thy mangled daughter here:
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thy other banish'd son, with this dear sight
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Struck pale and bloodless; and thy brother, I,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Even like a stony image, cold and numb.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Ah, now no more will I control thy griefs:
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Rend off thy silver hair, thy other hand
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Gnawing with thy teeth; and be this dismal sight
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: The closing up of our most wretched eyes;
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Now is a time to storm; why art thou still?
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Ha, ha, ha!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Why dost thou laugh? it fits not with this hour.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Why, I have not another tear to shed:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Besides, this sorrow is an enemy,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And would usurp upon my watery eyes
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And make them blind with tributary tears:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then which way shall I find Revenge's cave?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For these two heads do seem to speak to me,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And threat me I shall never come to bliss
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Till all these mischiefs be return'd again
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Even in their throats that have committed them.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come, let me see what task I have to do.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: You heavy people, circle me about,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That I may turn me to each one of you,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And swear unto my soul to right your wrongs.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: The vow is made. Come, brother, take a head;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And in this hand the other I will bear.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Lavinia, thou shalt be employ'd: these arms!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Bear thou my hand, sweet wench, between thy teeth.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As for thee, boy, go get thee from my sight;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thou art an exile, and thou must not stay:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Hie to the Goths, and raise an army there:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And, if you love me, as I think you do,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Let's kiss and part, for we have much to do.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Farewell Andronicus, my noble father,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: The wofull'st man that ever lived in Rome:
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Farewell, proud Rome; till Lucius come again,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: He leaves his pledges dearer than his life:
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Farewell, Lavinia, my noble sister;
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: O, would thou wert as thou tofore hast been!
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: But now nor Lucius nor Lavinia lives
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: But in oblivion and hateful griefs.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: If Lucius live, he will requite your wrongs;
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: And make proud Saturnine and his empress
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Beg at the gates, like Tarquin and his queen.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Now will I to the Goths, and raise a power,
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: To be revenged on Rome and Saturnine.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: So, so; now sit: and look you eat no more
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Than will preserve just so much strength in us
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As will revenge these bitter woes of ours.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Marcus, unknit that sorrow-wreathen knot:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thy niece and I, poor creatures, want our hands,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And cannot passionate our tenfold grief
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: With folded arms. This poor right hand of mine
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Is left to tyrannize upon my breast;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Who, when my heart, all mad with misery,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Beats in this hollow prison of my flesh,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then thus I thump it down.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thou map of woe, that thus dost talk in signs!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: When thy poor heart beats with outrageous beating,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thou canst not strike it thus to make it still.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Wound it with sighing, girl, kill it with groans;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Or get some little knife between thy teeth,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And just against thy heart make thou a hole;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That all the tears that thy poor eyes let fall
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: May run into that sink, and soaking in
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Drown the lamenting fool in sea-salt tears.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Fie, brother, fie! teach her not thus to lay
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Such violent hands upon her tender life.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: How now! has sorrow made thee dote already?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Why, Marcus, no man should be mad but I.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: What violent hands can she lay on her life?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Ah, wherefore dost thou urge the name of hands;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: To bid AEneas tell the tale twice o'er,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: How Troy was burnt and he made miserable?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O, handle not the theme, to talk of hands,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Lest we remember still that we have none.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Fie, fie, how franticly I square my talk,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As if we should forget we had no hands,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: If Marcus did not name the word of hands!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come, let's fall to; and, gentle girl, eat this:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Here is no drink! Hark, Marcus, what she says;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: I can interpret all her martyr'd signs;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: She says she drinks no other drink but tears,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Brew'd with her sorrow, mesh'd upon her cheeks:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Speechless complainer, I will learn thy thought;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: In thy dumb action will I be as perfect
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: As begging hermits in their holy prayers:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Thou shalt not sigh, nor hold thy stumps to heaven,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Nor wink, nor nod, nor kneel, nor make a sign,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But I of these will wrest an alphabet
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And by still practise learn to know thy meaning.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Young LUCIUS
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Good grandsire, leave these bitter deep laments:
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Make my aunt merry with some pleasing tale.
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Alas, the tender boy, in passion moved,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Doth weep to see his grandsire's heaviness.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Peace, tender sapling; thou art made of tears,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And tears will quickly melt thy life away.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: What dost thou strike at, Marcus, with thy knife?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: At that that I have kill'd, my lord; a fly.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Out on thee, murderer! thou kill'st my heart;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Mine eyes are cloy'd with view of tyranny:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: A deed of death done on the innocent
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Becomes not Titus' brother: get thee gone:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: I see thou art not for my company.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Alas, my lord, I have but kill'd a fly.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But how, if that fly had a father and mother?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: How would he hang his slender gilded wings,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And buzz lamenting doings in the air!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Poor harmless fly,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That, with his pretty buzzing melody,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Came here to make us merry! and thou hast
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: kill'd him.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Pardon me, sir; it was a black ill-favor'd fly,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Like to the empress' Moor; therefore I kill'd him.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: O, O, O,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Then pardon me for reprehending thee,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: For thou hast done a charitable deed.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Give me thy knife, I will insult on him;
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Flattering myself, as if it were the Moor
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come hither purposely to poison me.--
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: There's for thyself, and that's for Tamora.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Ah, sirrah!
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Yet, I think, we are not brought so low,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But that between us we can kill a fly
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: That comes in likeness of a coal-black Moor.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Alas, poor man! grief has so wrought on him,
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: He takes false shadows for true substances.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come, take away. Lavinia, go with me:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: I'll to thy closet; and go read with thee
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Sad stories chanced in the times of old.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come, boy, and go with me: thy sight is young,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And thou shalt read when mine begin to dazzle.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Young LUCIUS
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Help, grandsire, help! my aunt Lavinia
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Follows me every where, I know not why:
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Good uncle Marcus, see how swift she comes.
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Alas, sweet aunt, I know not what you mean.
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Stand by me, Lucius; do not fear thine aunt.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: She loves thee, boy, too well to do thee harm.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Young LUCIUS
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Ay, when my father was in Rome she did.
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: What means my niece Lavinia by these signs?
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Fear her not, Lucius: somewhat doth she mean:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: See, Lucius, see how much she makes of thee:
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Somewhither would she have thee go with her.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Ah, boy, Cornelia never with more care
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Read to her sons than she hath read to thee
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Sweet poetry and Tully's Orator.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Canst thou not guess wherefore she plies thee thus?
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Young LUCIUS
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: My lord, I know not, I, nor can I guess,
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Unless some fit or frenzy do possess her:
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: For I have heard my grandsire say full oft,
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Extremity of griefs would make men mad;
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: And I have read that Hecuba of Troy
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Ran mad through sorrow: that made me to fear;
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Although, my lord, I know my noble aunt
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Loves me as dear as e'er my mother did,
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: And would not, but in fury, fright my youth:
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Which made me down to throw my books, and fly--
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: Causeless, perhaps. But pardon me, sweet aunt:
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: And, madam, if my uncle Marcus go,
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: I will most willingly attend your ladyship.
lines.speaker: Young LUCIUS

lines.value: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Lucius, I will.
lines.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: TITUS ANDRONICUS
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: How now, Lavinia! Marcus, what means this?
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Some book there is that she desires to see.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Which is it, girl, of these? Open them, boy.
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: But thou art deeper read, and better skill'd
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: Come, and take choice of all my library,
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.value: And so beguile thy sorrow, till the heavens
lines.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Complots of mischief, treason, villanies
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Ruthful to hear, yet piteously perform'd:
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And this shall all be buried by my death,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Tell on thy mind; I say thy child shall live.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Swear that he shall, and then I will begin.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: Who should I swear by? thou believest no god:

lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: What if I do not? as, indeed, I do not;
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Yet, for I know thou art religious
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And hast a thing within thee called conscience,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: With twenty popish tricks and ceremonies,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Which I have seen thee careful to observe,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: By that same god, what god soe'er it be,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: That thou adorest and hast in reverence,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: To save my boy, to nourish and bring him up;

lines.value: Or else I will discover nought to thee.

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: First know thou, I begot him on the empress.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: O most insatiate and luxurious woman!
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Tut, Lucius, this was but a deed of charity
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: O detestable villain! call'st thou that trimming?
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Why, she was wash'd and cut and trimm'd, and 'twas
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Trim sport for them that had the doing of it.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: O barbarous, beastly villains, like thyself!
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: AARON
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Indeed, I was their tutor to instruct them:
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: That codding spirit had they from their mother,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: As sure a card as ever won the set;
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: That bloody mind, I think, they learn'd of me,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: As true a dog as ever fought at head.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Well, let my deeds be witness of my worth.
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: I train'd thy brethren to that guileful hole
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Where the dead corpse of Bassianus lay:
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: I wrote the letter that thy father found
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And hid the gold within the letter mention'd,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Confederate with the queen and her two sons:
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And what not done, that thou hast cause to rue,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Wherein I had no stroke of mischief in it?
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: I play'd the cheater for thy father's hand,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And, when I had it, drew myself apart
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And almost broke my heart with extreme laughter:
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: I pry'd me through the crevice of a wall
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: When, for his hand, he had his two sons' heads;
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: Beheld his tears, and laugh'd so heartily,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: That both mine eyes were rainy like to his :
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: And when I told the empress of this sport,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.value: She swooned almost at my pleasing tale,
lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON

lines.speaker: AARON
